docs.lead_paragraph: This was not the typical audience for a medical conference, but then again, this was no typical conference. At an inn set in the lush farmland of Lancaster County, doctors attending scientific lectures earlier this month were joined by young Mennonite and Amish couples, the women in bonnets and the men in suspenders, babies fussing in their laps. The Amish and Mennonites may travel by horse and buggy and forgo most modern conveniences, but there is one bit of progress that they are eager to embrace: gene therapy.

headline.main: At Gene Therapy's Frontier, the Amish Build a Clinic

docs.abstract: Three children from Amish and Mennonite communities in Strasburg, Pa, will become first human beings to test new method of gene therapy to treat Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, rare but deadly inherited disease in which waste product called bilirubin builds up in body and cannot be excreted; Amish and Mennonites have very high rates of variety of genetic disorders, because of their practice of intermarrying; new gene therapy, chimeraplasty, is intended to stimulate patient's own cells to repair defect in gene, using molecule called chimeraplast, manufactured blend of DNA and related molecule RNA; Dr Holmes Morton, who treats children for Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, runs nonprofit Clinic for Special Children from building that Amish and Mennonite community built for him; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Medicare beneficiary could eventually get up to $2,500 a year in Federal money to help buy prescription drugs under President Clinton's proposal to expand the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, Administration officials said tonight. Mr. Clinton promised Medicare coverage of prescription drugs in his State of the Union Message on Jan. 19. But Administration officials were still working out the last details this evening, just a day before Mr. Clinton plans to unveil the proposal.

headline.main: Drug Benefits Up to $2,500 Are in Plan For Medicare

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration officials say Medicare beneficiary could eventually get up to $2,500 per year in Federal money to help buy prescription drugs under President's proposal to expand health insurance program for the elderly and disabled; drug benefits are one element of comprehensive plan Clinton has devised to modernize Medicare and strengthen its financial condition (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A small segment of physicians seeks to unionize, with American Medical Association approval, to defend themselves and their patients (front page, June 24). They are trying to preserve their professionalism. Yet it was professionalism that historically empowered doctors. Their patients were their bosses, and they were free to go elsewhere.

headline.main: Medicare Drugs: Let the Wealthy Pay
